node.title: Compiling issues on macOS Ventura 13.1

Hello everyone!
I am using macOS, and recently I have run into compiling issues.
When I compile moose and my applications, the process stops with the errors below:

make: *** [/Users/providence/MOOSE_Ubuntu_to_MAC/moose/framework/app.mk:345: /Users/providence/MOOSE_Ubuntu_to_MAC/moose/modules/fluid_properties/lib/libfluid_properties-opt.la] Error 1
make: *** Waiting for unfinished jobs....

The compilation went well half a month ago, and I don't know if it's because I've updated my system and downloaded gcc from homebrew or anything else.
Could anyone please help fix it? Much Thanks!!

Hello
if you are using macOS then you need to use the conda environment to build moose.
I think right now you are trying to build with your systems compiler
Guillaume

I am using conda environment to build moose.
Before compiling, I used
mamba init
mamba activate moose

I have also reinstalled the mamba environment, but it didn't work.

When I use
clang -v

It comes out
clang version 12.0.1
Target: arm64-apple-darwin22.2.0
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /Users/providence/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin

So I think the compiler I am using is in the moose environment directory.

Ok that's good.
Can you please paste the output of the diagnostics script in moose/scripts

OMG, I think I know the reason...
I downloaded another mpich from homebrew, and when I compiled the moose application, it used homebrew-mpich rather than moose-mpich...
I have just uninstalled homebrew-mpich and then the compilation succeeds.
The thing is, I need homebrew-mpich to compile other programs. Any suggestion on maintaining both types of mpich without compilation errors?

You should be able to find a working mpi compiler from mamba.
Homebrew doesnt let you deactivate things easily, you will have to set environment variables to point to what you want to use all the time
Thank you! I will later try setting environmental variables.

I want to add:
You're welcome to use any compiler you like (so long as it constrains to our minimums: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/sqa/minimum_requirements.html). Please keep in mind when not using our prepackaged binaries of libMesh, PETSc, etc... you'll need to build these on your own, and each time you see us post an update to either of the two.
We provide a script for such purposes, and we will happily support folks using Homebrew:
brew install mpich
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx, etc # basically all things necessary to use the MPI wrapper 
gcc|clang --version             # verify the compiler is something we support

cd ~/projects/moose/scripts
export MOOSE_JOBS=6             # or however many cores your machine has
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
As @GiudGiud mentioned, it is not easy to maintain both. With Conda, you can switch things off with: conda deactivate, or activate some other special environment (like ours with conda activate moose).

node.title: Scalability
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I would like to know if anyone has a scalability curve of moose.
I will ask for computing time on a national computing center and would like to give them
an approximation of our needs.
Our simulations couple Crystal plasticity (1000 grains) with phase field damage and CZM.
The number of DOF goes from 2 millions to 20 millions.
thanks for any help
regards,
sab

Hello
Scalability is application dependent as the numerical system is not solved the same way for every physics.
@permcody might know the right paper for scalability of the phase field module
The rule of thumb we use is 20k dofs at least per processor, so for 20M we would say use less than 1,000 processors but it's likely to work with much less.
Guillaume

See the moose softwarex paper. The framework scales very, very well to tens of thousands cores. However, I have limited success in scaling a crystalplasiticity + czm simulation. The bottleneck is a scalable linear solver. I think you might go to several hundreds cores, beyond that is gonna be a hard stretch. There's something else that didn't scale well when I have both czm (mesh broken) and periodic strain conditions. I can't recall exactly what that was on top of my head right now.

node.title: execute_on second time step
node.bodyText: I am wondering if it is possible to evaluate an AuxVariable at the second time step (as opposed to the first with execute_on = 'initial').

Hello
You can. You ll want to execute on timestep_begin and use a Control (this one I think: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/controls/ConditionalFunctionEnableControl.html)
to turn the auxkernel on then off
Guillaume

I reduced the time step to dt=0.1, and I got a convergence error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "TimeStepper", of type "ConstantDT".

Solve failed and timestep already at or below dtmin, cannot continue!

I’m using a 3D model with only 1 element in all 3 (x-y-z) directions. I output the model as an exodus file using additional_execute_on = FAILED, and I can view it in ParaView, but I’m unsure how to view the element causing the problem. Any leads? Thanks.
There's only one element? Then that's the one that's causing trouble
Does it move through the transient?

Hello,
Yes, it is a 1x1x1 unit cube, and the element moves during the (transient) simulation.

  
    
    

    20230113_215651.mp4
At 9s in the video the element goes to 0 volume then flips. Is this when you get the negative Jacobian error?

Hello,
No. It appears that the negative jacobian is responsible for the flip but does not exclusively occur at the end. It occurs at multiple timesteps. The flip is associated with the jagged lines toward the end of my curve. I have realized that this error occurs only when I increase the applied load; if the load is small, I don’t see the error, and I don’t see the jagged lines. I think it is safe to say that the model is working properly.

Hello @GiudGiud,
I'm re-opening this ticket because I'm getting the same 'negative jacobian' error when I increase the duration of my simulation. The simulation runs well for about 80 days without a problem and with good results. When I increase the simulation time beyond 80 days, it starts to give me an error. Any help on this issue, please? Thanks.

What does the mesh look like at that time?
The system should give you the id of the element that has the negative jacobian.
That element might become flat or inverted at that time step.

Hello @GiudGiud. Thanks for the response.
Perhaps the problem is with my choice of model params. If I change the value of some params, the model runs to the specified time (even up to 250 days). I think some of the model parameters I'm working with are incorrect. I'm waiting for feedback about the model params; I'll let you know once I have these params and the issue persists. Thanks.

node.title: Can the fixed value BC be set in thermal-hydraulic module？
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I know the boundary condition in thermal-hydraulic module (THM) is inherited from the IntergralBC of MOOSE. So we need to define the flux at the boundary, which may cause the variable value not to be fixed at the boundary. Can the fixed value BC (variable value at BC is a given constant value) be used in THM?
Thank you!
Best regard

Is there anyone kindly tell me？
Thank you.

@joshuahansel
I looked through the tests in modules/thermalhydraulics and didnt see any DirichletBCs on fluid variables.
That's correct.

There aren't any components that use Dirichlet BCs on any fluid variables - we universally use weak, "ghost cell" boundary conditions. I don't remember exactly why this is the case:

The fluid variables are CONST MONOMIAL, so their values live at element centers, not nodes. I don't know if Dirichlet BCs are possible for elemental variables (@GiudGiud?). I believe we at least decided that it didn't make much sense to prescribe the boundary element center values.
The other equations would probably have their BCs computed weakly, and it would need to be consistent with the Dirichlet BC value. This may be difficult/impossible.

Thanks for your reply.

I don't know if Dirichlet BCs are possible for elemental variables.

The DirichletBC is not available for elemental variables. Does that mean THM can't set fix value BC?  If we want to let the variable value of the first element as far as possible equal to what we set in the ghost cell, the only way is to refine the grid.
Thank you!
I believe that's correct.

Hi joshuahansel，
Thank you for your reply. Could you kindly answer another question I have?
In ADBoundaryFlux3EqnGhostBase.C, the ghost cell variables are calculated by the type of boundary and the variables in the interior cell. And then the boundary flux is calculated by the variable in the ghost and interior cell according to the chosen numerical method. What I want to know is why the left boundary and right boundary can use the same expression.
( flux = _numerical_flux.getFlux(iside, ielem, true, U1, U2, normal(0));)
In the right boundary, the ghost cell is on the right and the interior cell is on the left. This expression is exactly correct. However, in the left boundary, the ghost cell is on the left and the interior cell is on the right, so I think it should be
( flux =_numerical_flux.getFlux(iside, ielem, false, U2, U1, normal(0));)
It really confused me. Could you tell me the reason?
Thank you very much!!

Good question. Basically, first the flux is computed in a reference space with the first argument on the left and the second argument on the right, and then it is transformed using normal(0), which is equal to +1 for the case that the ordering is left, right, and it's -1 for right, left.

That's right, it's in ADNumericalFlux3EqnHLLC. And yes, if you don't have it in there, what you have is correct, other than that you shouldn't check equality of floating point numbers; you should do MooseUtils::absoluteFuzzyEqual(normal(0), 1.0) for example.
Thank you very much! Much appreciate!

Hello


In the first profile you posted (deleted now), it was intel compilers. We do not support these.


In the current profile, you are using a compiler older than the minimum supported.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/sqa/minimum_requirements.html
Can you load a newer one on your HPC platform?


Guillaume

I set up the environment based on the HCP admin's recommendation.
I will load a higher version of GCC and rebuild everything.
Are the following gnu and openmpi good enough?
module purge
module load modules
module load gnu/7.3.0
module load openmpi/1.10.7
module load cmake/3.20.5
7.3 is below the minimum mentioned. What’s important is that it supports C++17
Thanks! I used gnu/11.2 and that solved the issue.

So this is not the issue...

FYI, I have the same error on Fedora 37.
Even after a clean MOOSE install and on two different systems (both running Fedora).

Interesting to hear someone else is I having the same issue. I too have tried multiple clean builds. I have installed moose quite a few times before (although not recently and not on this machine) and have never came across this issue before.

Must be some sort of conflict with the way we build VTK within Conda. I'll start up a Apptainer using Fedora 37, and see if I can reproduce (Monday)...
To get around this, you can instead only install moose-petsc instead of moose-libmesh. And then run ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh manually. The gist of what I am getting at:
mamba deactivate
mamba activate base
mamba env remove -n moose
mamba create -n moose moose-petsc moose-tools
mamba activate moose
cd ~/projects/moose
git clean -xfd              # start fresh
export MOOSE_JOBS=6         # the number of cores available to you 
export METHODS=opt          # build only the optimized version of libMesh
scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
cd test
make -j $MOOSE_JOBS
./run_tests -j $MOOSE_JOBS
Thanks @milljm I will give this a try

node.title: Re-declaration of Params
node.bodyText:
Hi, I have a trivial question.
When inheriting from a parent class, do I have to re-declare parameters common to the parent and child class in the child class? I'm getting the following declaration error, but I don't want to duplicate these parameters in the child class.
error: '_M' was not declared in this scope

Hello
no you should have not have to, you can ininitalize the input parameters using the validParams() from the parent class.
however here you seem to be asking about a class attribute. You should not have to either
Guillaume

error: '_M' was not declared in this scope

The error message is precise: the compiler cannot find a member named _M. Two typical causes of that are:

You forgot to declare that member in the header.
_M is supposed to be inherited from the parent class, but _M is private in the parent class.

Hi @GiudGiud @hugary1995:
I can’t seem to figure a way out of this issue. _M is protected in the parent class. Since I’m inheriting, I should not declare it in the child. I’m still getting the declaration error. Here is the part of my header showing the inheritance:
template <bool is_ad>
class UpdatedMflowTempl : public MflowBaseTempl<is_ad>

ok. i got it now
I should have use the following in the header: using MflowBaseTempl<is_ad>::_M;

Ha, yes. That's unfortunately necessary as _M is a non-dependent name, i.e., it doesn't depend on any template argument. The compiler tries to look it up early before template instantiation. To make it dependent you'll have to do one of the following:

using MflowBaseTempl<is_ad>::_M; as you've discovered.
use this->_M
use MflowBaseTempl<is_ad>::_M

node.title: Artificially update variables after each time step in TimeDerivative kernel
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I have a question.  After each time step, we solve the PDEs and get the variable values.
But now if I want to artificially do some changes to one variable, for example, multiply it with a constant value after each time step and use the artificially changed value as the input (or old value) for the next time step.
How to easily achieve that?
Thanks in advance.
J

Hello
So we generally dont allow that, because a nonlinear variable is the output of solver an equation not any other pre-determined operation like multiplying it. If you just want a multiplied value from a variable, that's more what the auxiliary variables are for.
However, if you do want to do that, you can use a MultiApp to do that:

transfer the non linear variable to an auxvariable in a MultiApp on timestep_end
use an auxkernel to multiply the variable there, for example the ParsedAux
transfer the value back from the auxvariable to the nonlinear variable in the main app

Another option is to write a custom user object to do the multipliciation. This requires coding.
Guillaume
